The **orb of enchantment** was a tool that appeared in [NetHack Plus](/wiki/NetHack_Plus "NetHack Plus") and [SLASH 6](/wiki/SLASH_6 "SLASH 6"). It appeared as a [glass orb](/wiki/Glass_orb "Glass orb") when unidentified.

In [SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM"), the orb is a [deferred feature](/wiki/Deferred_feature "Deferred feature") - its code can still be found in the SLASH'EM source, but has been commented out with the note of "potential for abuse".[\[1\]](#cite_note-1)[\[2\]](#cite_note-2)

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Effects](#Effects)
- [2 Strategy](#Strategy)
- [3 Messages](#Messages)
- [4 References](#References)

## Effects

[Applying](/wiki/Apply "Apply") a charged orb of enchantment alters the enchantment of your primary wielded weapon, somewhat similar to a [scroll of enchant weapon](/wiki/Scroll_of_enchant_weapon "Scroll of enchant weapon"); this only works on items in the [weapon](/wiki/Weapon "Weapon") and [weapon-tool](/wiki/Weapon-tool "Weapon-tool") class. The effect varies dependent on the orb's [beatitude](/wiki/Beatitude "Beatitude"):

- If blessed, the orb will always attempt to increase the enchantment, with a 50% chance of increasing it by 1 and a 50% chance of increasing it by 2. (*"Your \<weapon> glows silver"*).
- If uncursed, the orb has a 2-in-3 chance of increasing the enchantment by 1 (*"Your \<weapon> glows bright for a moment"*), and a 1-in-3 chance of decreasing it by 1. (*"Your \<weapon> glows dark for a moment"*).
- If cursed, the orb will always attempt to decrease the enchantment, with a 50% chance of decreasing it by 1 and a 50% chance of decreasing it by 2. (*"Your \<weapon> glows black"*).

The maximum for enchantment via the orb is +5 - if a weapon that was +4 would have gained 2 points of enchantment, it will cut off at +5, and the orb will have no effect on a +5 weapon.

Nothing will happen when applying an orb of enchantment with no charges.

## Strategy

All non-[crystal ball](/wiki/Crystal_ball "Crystal ball") glass orbs have a base price of 750 [zm](/wiki/Zm "Zm") and weigh 75 [aum](/wiki/Aum "Aum"), making it somewhat easier to tell an actual crystal ball apart from the other magical orbs. Beyond this, the three non-crystal ball orbs can only be distinguished by [identification](/wiki/Identification "Identification") or use-testing.

## Messages

- Your \<weapon> glows silver.

  You applied a blessed orb of enchantment.

- Your \<weapon> glows bright for a moment.

  You applied an uncursed orb of enchantment, and it increased your weapon's enchantment.

- Your \<weapon> glows dark for a moment.

  You applied an uncursed orb of enchantment, and it decreased your weapon's enchantment.

- Your \<weapon> glows black.

  You applied a cursed orb of enchantment.

- This orb is burnt out.

  The orb of enchantment had no charges.

## References

1. [↑](#cite_ref-1) [apply.c in SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2, line 3570](/wiki/Source:SLASH%27EM_0.0.7E7F2/apply.c#line3570 "Source:SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2/apply.c")
2. [↑](#cite_ref-2) [objects.c in SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2, line 858](/wiki/Source:SLASH%27EM_0.0.7E7F2/objects.c#line858 "Source:SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2/objects.c")

The orb of enchantment was a tool that appeared in NetHack Plus and SLASH 6. It appeared as a glass orb when unidentified.

In SLASH'EM, the orb is a deferred feature - its code can still be found in the SLASH'EM source, but has been commented out with the note of "potential for abuse".[1][2]

Effects

Applying a charged orb of enchantment alters the enchantment of your primary wielded weapon, somewhat similar to a scroll of enchant weapon; this only works on items in the weapon and weapon-tool class. The effect varies dependent on the orb's beatitude:

  • If blessed, the orb will always attempt to increase the enchantment, with a 50% chance of increasing it by 1 and a 50% chance of increasing it by 2. ("Your <weapon> glows silver").

All non-crystal ball glass orbs have a base price of 750 zm and weigh 75 aum, making it somewhat easier to tell an actual crystal ball apart from the other magical orbs. Beyond this, the three non-crystal ball orbs can only be distinguished by identification or use-testing.
